intro: Scolopendrium ceterach, commonly known as the Irish fern, is a species of fern belonging to the family Polypodiaceae. It is characterized by its delicate, lance-shaped fronds that are typically 30–60 cm long. The plant produces sporangia on the underside of its leaves, which are clustered in small groups called sori. It thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Scolopendrium ceterach is a perennial plant that is well adapted to temperate climates.
